children.name: Instagram
caption:
Based on how hard I’m laughing in this picture, yesterday was clearly another successful day in the mountains! I don’t know what was so funny in this exact moment, but find things (hobbies, experiences, people, etc) in life that make you laugh this hard and keep them close.
.
.
.
Yesterday morning started out at -2 degrees, but it still turned out to be a gorgeous day for a hike up Nineteen Mile Brook & Wildcat Ridge. We stopped at the #carternotchhut to warm up & eat before and after reaching the summit of Wildcat which added some time to our hike. We clocked out for the day at around 10 miles, 8 hours, 32,000 steps, and one more peak crossed off the list.
.
.
.
✅ Wildcat Mountain - Peak A (4422’) # 33 | 48
.
.
.

children.name: Instagram
caption: Peak bagged 8 4000 footers in 2 days, covering over 42miles with over 14000” elevation gain. Great stay at AMC huts, #galeheadhut #zealandfallhut failed insulin pump due to freezing cold body sweat, manual blouses with pump syringes was hectic and painful. Failed dexcomg6 and manual pricks wasn’t helpful on strenuous hikes. Muddy trails after a heavy downpour almost makes hiking very hard with over 45lb of backpack. Sprained foot and hikers feet, each day covering over 20 miles on mountain with multitude of blood sugars was very much exhausting. It’s always good to know your limits and move further based on that. Sometimes, it’s okay to back down irrespective of the outcomes. One should be proud of the achievements and hard work and not delve in the past. Had i moved forward with another day of hiking. I would have had terrible outcome. I’m glad that i was able to hike in the peak fall season and had a great views of the New England weather!! #newengland #newhampshire #hikingadventures #hiking #t1d #omnipodinsulinpump #dexcomg6 #diabetesawareness #fallhiking #mountgarfield #northtwin #southtwin #galehead #galeheadhut #appalachiantrail #appalachianmountains #bondmountain #zealand #zealandfallshut #4000footers #peakbagging #freezingweather #outdooradventures #keepmovingforward #latergram #motivationmonday

children.name: Instagram
caption: Found this shot buried in a hard drive today while looking for stills from our Merrimack film project. I shot this back in the fall of 2016 from Zeacliff in the White Mountains. This valley in the Pemigewasset Wilderness Area is one of the farthest upstream reaches in the Merrimack River watershed.  I think @__nightmute was there that morning (how have you been buddy?). And I believe I spent the night in one of my favorite backcountry cabins - Zealand Falls Hut. #pemigewassetwilderness #whitemountains #newhampshire #newengland #merrimackriver #themerrimackriveratrisk #indiefilm #appalachiantrail

children.name: Instagram
caption: An arduous and triumphant backpacking adventure with my stalwart companion and unbreakable explorer, @ariana__moran, through Harriman State Park, NY. Woke up to an inch of snow and foraging deer our first morning. Day 2 got off course (Harriman is a maze of intersecting and confusing trails, the AT being 1 of more than 15) and ended up at a beautifully maintained shelter, #fingerboardshelter (last picture, sunrise unity, sunrise from the pillow) where we had company within minutes. In comes Grizzly Gramps, a gregarious 65 yr old Appalachian trail through-hiker nearing his 1500dth mile, who took the picture of us in the light of the sunrise on our third day. We are blessed to be afforded these perspectives of the natural spender of the Earth. I am grateful and feel blessed to partake in the bounty of crisp morning air and the next peak to bag blocking the horizon. harrimanstatepark #BACKPACKING #adventurecouple #appalachiantrail #friendsofthetrail #leavenotrace #adventure #asquared #toomanypicturestopost #baggingpeaks #ny #newyork #ineedtostartablog #hiking #wilderness #getoutside #gottagetuptogetdown

children.name: Instagram
caption:
Hello, Virginia! A new @yoho.co collection is headed to new stockist @campingcampingcamping in Sperryville, Virginia. 
Happy Camper Equipment Co. sits at the base of Shenandoah National Park in this sweet, small southern town, 70 miles outside of Washington DC. 
Just down the street is one of the main entrances to Shenandoah National Park, so Sperryville is  a Mecca for weekend and day trip adventure seekers. 
Also, one of the East Coast’s most famous hiking destinations, Old Rag, is just steps from Sperryville. The Shenandoah Mountains are famous for the Appalachian Trail and Skyline Drive. It’s an incredibly beautiful part of the world! 
We’re so excited to have HCECo. join as a new stockist. Their exclusive @yoho.co pennants are on the way and expected to arrive next week. 🚩
.
.
.

“Hiking Old Rag: Shenandoah’s Most Famous [& Oddest Named] Trail”
.
I had never been to Shenandoah - so with a rare day off, I decided to make a day-trip from DC to cross this National Park off my list. I woke on my boat at 5:30 am and hit the road!
.

Water signs love water, and hikers love hiking. This week, a friend joined us to combine the two, along with plenty of ascent. The air was crisp and the sun shone as we climbed from 1,100’ to 4,200’ at the top of Hawksbill. From there, we walked the west side of the ridge for a few miles on the AT before heading back down into the canyon. Snix rocked out the 14 miles, and I sounded a few barbaric yawps for good measure.

Reaching Big Meadows in Shenandoah National Park marked the 100 mile mark for my journey. To celebrate, I decided to take a zero day there. (A zero day is when you take an entire day off from hiking.) The meadow itself was about a mile off trail but it was definitely worth the walk. Meandering along the deer trails in this mountaintop meadow during sunset was probably my favorite moment of this whole trip. It's during sunset that deer become most active and come out into the meadow to graze. It was truly a sight worth seeing.
-
"7/20/18 - Took a zero the day before yesterday at Big Meadows campground. Real nice place. Showers! If you stop at the wayside make sure you also go out into the meadow. Real pretty place. Mostly because it was out of the trees!" - Bearfence Mountain Hut register

Year: 2019
State: 8/50 Virginia 
US National Park: Shenandoah National Park ( 8/62)
************************************************************
2019 brought with it limited travel, high stress, and a series of health issues. I quit my full time job in June and decided to re-establish a full time private practice and start taking care of myself. Decided I needed a road trip and with it came a  reconnection  with a high school friend who lives in Virginia. She wanted an adventure and I wanted to cross off a bucket list hike so off to McAfee Knob we went! It’s one of the most photographed sections of the Appalachian Trail. I hope to see it at sunrise in 2020. On the way home my NJ friend/colleague/hiking partner decided to make a detour to Shenandoah National Park. Didn’t get any hiking in but drove the scenic route all the way North until we couldn’t. The 9 hour ride home took about 15 hours. But well worth it. ************************************************************ #badasshikingwomen #womenwhoexplore  #womenwhohike #adventuregirls #52hikechallenge #allwomenalltrails #hikerbabesorg100 #sheexplores #journeyto100,  #keepexploring #exploremore #appalachiantrail #mcafeeknob #bucketlisthike  #virginiaisbeautiful #virginiaisforlovers #shenandoahnationalpark

children.name: Instagram
caption: This is @deucestarmount (Matt) and Alex about 24-25 years ago. Matt has been contemplating #hiking the #appalachiantrail for longer than Alex has been alive. I’m traveling full-time, so this is a perfect time for him to realize a major bucket list task. I thought I was handling the idea of him being gone quite well. If I was going to get emotional, I thought it would have been when I dropped him off at the #springermountain trailhead or drove from Georgia to Virginia alone. Nope. Nothing until last night, when it finally hit me that he’s likely going to be gone until summer. Welp. Water works. 😭😭😭 It’s fine. It’s going to go by fast. I mean, it feels like we *just* met and that was more than 13 years ago. I would never dream of asking him to come home because I want him to finish possibly almost as much as he does. I’m so happy that he gets to have an adventure. I’m also excited to re-experience some of the things that I enjoyed when I was single. I don’t remember what those things were, but as soon as I do, I’m sure I will be happy to do them again! Matt, if you’re reading this, I miss you so much and I’m so proud of you for making a dream come true! I love you! ❤️❤️❤️ #appalachiantrailclassof2020 #appalachiantrail2020

‘Twas the week before Christmas and all through the house, not a creature was stirring not even a mouse. So what do we do?  We begin section hiking the AT. 
This section was Springer Mountain to Hawk Mountain Shelter and back.  We begin at the Springer Mountain parking lot on a Friday after work, hiking up to the summit of Springer Mountain, capturing our first of many amazing sunsets on the AT.  What a way to end the week and begin an awesome new chapter in the Happy Hiking Couple book. ❤️ Saturday we awoke to a frosty ground but our NorthFace Wasatch sleeping bags kept us toasty warm @thenorthface .

There was a mouse stirring at the Springer Mountain Shelter by our campsite. I screamed.  Poor little thing just wanted some good food.  We cooked up some tasty noodles and salmon. 
Saturday morning we hiked to Hawk Mountain Shelter, stopping along the way at Three Forks and beautiful Long Creek Falls.  We slept very well at Hawk Mountain and hiked back to Springer Mountain parking lot through the rain on Sunday morning. 
Lessons learned this week: —Lesson 1—Proper footwear is essential.  Christy lost toenails! Yuck!🤢 —
—Lesson 2—Because you have a pocket doesn’t mean you have to put something in it.  This is when Christy earned her trail name “Pockets.” She had her pockets stuffed so full she couldn’t fasten her waist belt in her pack! Can you say, “Ralphie from A Christmas Story?” 🤣🤣🤣 —
—Lesson 3—Cotton kills....at least on the trail.  It became time to buy some merino wool. 
Gear we tried this week and love:
—Don’s Salomon X- Mission-3 trail runners @salomon —North Face Wasatch Sleeping Bags—@thenorthface—bought for a smoking deal at @rei —Don’s Kelty trekking poles. @keltybuilt , purchased for a great deal at #smokeymountaintrader in Cleveland, Ga.

Went searching for snow yesterday morning, and found snow and ice both! I was so enthralled by this huge icy wall that I couldn’t stop staring at it and touching it. You could hear the water flowing behind the thick ice, and it made the prettiest trickling sound. So peaceful! I know a lot of people don’t like winter, but it’s my second favorite season, right behind fall. There’s so much beauty in the winter! 🧊❄️

caption:
AT mile 319.7. Day 14. Taking an unexpected zero day!

I was trying not to take any zeroes until New Jersey, but my right knee has been swollen for just about a week now, so I figure I need to let it heal so I can stay strong for the whole year. I’m staying at Mother Marian’s hostel in Madison County, North Carolina (pictures 1 and 2). Pacing myself isn’t one of my strong suits. My mileage has fluctuated like 25-40-13-35-0. I feel good, but the knee is weighing on me. I’m focused on consistency and recovery now so I can get the miles up while staying healthy.

Also, here’s some random photos from the Smokies since I haven’t posted in a while!

My water filter froze last night from a brutal wind chill alone, so I took an unexpected ride into Gatlinburg for a replacement. I got a ride into town from some nice local gals who picked me up because I’m “a thru hiker, like Dixie!” Downtown Gatlinburg is a strange place, it reminds me a lot of seaside heights on the jersey shore, but it’s next to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park instead of the beach. I enjoyed the tremendous hospitality of the Lodge of Legends (@lodgeoflegends), which a trail angel runs out of the lower floor of her cabin. She plans to thru hike in 5 years after her son graduates high school. She’s incredibly kind and even gave me a knee brace for my super swollen knee. She inspires me to make the most of my hike and to pay it forward afterwards. Also met @the_champ_hikes who’s finishing up his thru hike from last year through the Smokies. Good luck, Champ!

So on Sunday I tried again and I made it to the AT! I can’t begin to explain how it felt to be back here again. It was bitterly cold and there was a strong wind whipping across Newfound Gap. I tried to hike for a mile or so but the trail was covered with snow and ice. It was too slippery. I was just overjoyed to have my feet on this path again and to have the white blazes calling me home. ❤️#appalachiantrail #atthruhike2019 #newfoundgap #greatsmokymountainsnationalpark #whiteblaze

Cades Cove is an 11 mile driving loop in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Generally, it takes 1-2 hours to drive through the whole loop because of all the traffic. It’s almost impossible to go to the cove without seeing another person. HOWEVER, the loop is closed to cars until February due to construction. The other day, me and 6 friends hiked 15.4 miles total to walk into Cades Cove and out again. Cold and tough, but soooo worth it to have alone time in the cove
.

Went searching for snow yesterday morning, and found snow and ice both! I was so enthralled by this huge icy wall that I couldn’t stop staring at it and touching it. You could hear the water flowing behind the thick ice, and it made the prettiest trickling sound. So peaceful! I know a lot of people don’t like winter, but it’s my second favorite season, right behind fall. There’s so much beauty in the winter! 🧊❄️

children.name: Instagram
caption:
AT mile 319.7. Day 14. Taking an unexpected zero day!

I was trying not to take any zeroes until New Jersey, but my right knee has been swollen for just about a week now, so I figure I need to let it heal so I can stay strong for the whole year. I’m staying at Mother Marian’s hostel in Madison County, North Carolina (pictures 1 and 2). Pacing myself isn’t one of my strong suits. My mileage has fluctuated like 25-40-13-35-0. I feel good, but the knee is weighing on me. I’m focused on consistency and recovery now so I can get the miles up while staying healthy.

Also, here’s some random photos from the Smokies since I haven’t posted in a while!
#appalachiantrail #appalachianmountains #at2020 #appalachianmountains #appalachian #greatsmokymountainsnationalpark

My water filter froze last night from a brutal wind chill alone, so I took an unexpected ride into Gatlinburg for a replacement. I got a ride into town from some nice local gals who picked me up because I’m “a thru hiker, like Dixie!” Downtown Gatlinburg is a strange place, it reminds me a lot of seaside heights on the jersey shore, but it’s next to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park instead of the beach. I enjoyed the tremendous hospitality of the Lodge of Legends (@lodgeoflegends), which a trail angel runs out of the lower floor of her cabin. She plans to thru hike in 5 years after her son graduates high school. She’s incredibly kind and even gave me a knee brace for my super swollen knee. She inspires me to make the most of my hike and to pay it forward afterwards. Also met @the_champ_hikes who’s finishing up his thru hike from last year through the Smokies. Good luck, Champ!

Day two of my adventure led me to max patch overlooking the Blue Ridge Mountains. A grassy bald that was cleared in the 1800s for a pasture for cattle. If left unmanaged it would revert back to it's original state and reestablish its hardwood forests but the forest service maintains it. Keeping it in an early successional state due to the fact it is now host to a variety of unique plants and animals including migratory birds.

The views were incredible and I love how you can see the other side in my sunglasses.  The view was endless.

children.name: Instagram
caption: This is @deucestarmount (Matt) and Alex about 24-25 years ago. Matt has been contemplating #hiking the #appalachiantrail for longer than Alex has been alive. I’m traveling full-time, so this is a perfect time for him to realize a major bucket list task. I thought I was handling the idea of him being gone quite well. If I was going to get emotional, I thought it would have been when I dropped him off at the #springermountain trailhead or drove from Georgia to Virginia alone. Nope. Nothing until last night, when it finally hit me that he’s likely going to be gone until summer. Welp. Water works. 😭😭😭 It’s fine. It’s going to go by fast. I mean, it feels like we *just* met and that was more than 13 years ago. I would never dream of asking him to come home because I want him to finish possibly almost as much as he does. I’m so happy that he gets to have an adventure. I’m also excited to re-experience some of the things that I enjoyed when I was single. I don’t remember what those things were, but as soon as I do, I’m sure I will be happy to do them again! Matt, if you’re reading this, I miss you so much and I’m so proud of you for making a dream come true! I love you! ❤️❤️❤️ #appalachiantrailclassof2020 #appalachiantrail2020

I was lucky enough to share the start of this monumental moment of one of my dearest and oldest friends!  @cathi.morris made a life changing decision, to take a long walk; 2,200 miles and 14 states, that is, the Appalachian Mountains.  We spent the last few days in a slice of paradise nestled in the North Georgia Mtns.  Our cabin was at the base of Amicalola Falls. This beautiful area is the start of one of the approach trails  to the Appalachian mountains.  She starts her trek from Georgia to Maine!  God Speed, Friend.  So inspired by her, and I always have been!  Cathi and Andrew have been planning her trip and she has been training for well over a year!! She’s amazing, and can always use encouraging thoughts and prayers!  #hikingtheappalachiantrail #appalachiantrail #springermountain #cathimorrisalot #appalachiantrailthruhike2020 #appalachiantrailthruhike

‘Twas the week before Christmas and all through the house, not a creature was stirring not even a mouse. So what do we do?  We begin section hiking the AT. 
This section was Springer Mountain to Hawk Mountain Shelter and back.  We begin at the Springer Mountain parking lot on a Friday after work, hiking up to the summit of Springer Mountain, capturing our first of many amazing sunsets on the AT.  What a way to end the week and begin an awesome new chapter in the Happy Hiking Couple book. ❤️ Saturday we awoke to a frosty ground but our NorthFace Wasatch sleeping bags kept us toasty warm @thenorthface .

There was a mouse stirring at the Springer Mountain Shelter by our campsite. I screamed.  Poor little thing just wanted some good food.  We cooked up some tasty noodles and salmon. 
Saturday morning we hiked to Hawk Mountain Shelter, stopping along the way at Three Forks and beautiful Long Creek Falls.  We slept very well at Hawk Mountain and hiked back to Springer Mountain parking lot through the rain on Sunday morning. 
Lessons learned this week: —Lesson 1—Proper footwear is essential.  Christy lost toenails! Yuck!🤢 —
—Lesson 2—Because you have a pocket doesn’t mean you have to put something in it.  This is when Christy earned her trail name “Pockets.” She had her pockets stuffed so full she couldn’t fasten her waist belt in her pack! Can you say, “Ralphie from A Christmas Story?” 🤣🤣🤣 —
—Lesson 3—Cotton kills....at least on the trail.  It became time to buy some merino wool. 
Gear we tried this week and love:
—Don’s Salomon X- Mission-3 trail runners @salomon —North Face Wasatch Sleeping Bags—@thenorthface—bought for a smoking deal at @rei —Don’s Kelty trekking poles. @keltybuilt , purchased for a great deal at #smokeymountaintrader in Cleveland, Ga.

children.name: Instagram
caption:
‘Twas the week before Christmas and all through the house, not a creature was stirring not even a mouse. So what do we do?  We begin section hiking the AT. 
This section was Springer Mountain to Hawk Mountain Shelter and back.  We begin at the Springer Mountain parking lot on a Friday after work, hiking up to the summit of Springer Mountain, capturing our first of many amazing sunsets on the AT.  What a way to end the week and begin an awesome new chapter in the Happy Hiking Couple book. ❤️ Saturday we awoke to a frosty ground but our NorthFace Wasatch sleeping bags kept us toasty warm @thenorthface .

There was a mouse stirring at the Springer Mountain Shelter by our campsite. I screamed.  Poor little thing just wanted some good food.  We cooked up some tasty noodles and salmon. 
Saturday morning we hiked to Hawk Mountain Shelter, stopping along the way at Three Forks and beautiful Long Creek Falls.  We slept very well at Hawk Mountain and hiked back to Springer Mountain parking lot through the rain on Sunday morning. 
Lessons learned this week: —Lesson 1—Proper footwear is essential.  Christy lost toenails! Yuck!🤢 —
—Lesson 2—Because you have a pocket doesn’t mean you have to put something in it.  This is when Christy earned her trail name “Pockets.” She had her pockets stuffed so full she couldn’t fasten her waist belt in her pack! Can you say, “Ralphie from A Christmas Story?” 🤣🤣🤣 —
—Lesson 3—Cotton kills....at least on the trail.  It became time to buy some merino wool. 
Gear we tried this week and love:
—Don’s Salomon X- Mission-3 trail runners @salomon —North Face Wasatch Sleeping Bags—@thenorthface—bought for a smoking deal at @rei —Don’s Kelty trekking poles. @keltybuilt , purchased for a great deal at #smokeymountaintrader in Cleveland, Ga. 
#happyhiking #happyhikingcouple #happywanderers #appalachiantrail #welovehiking #happyhikers #hopefulwanderers #seekthetrails #notallthatwanderarelost #keltybuilt #springermountain #hawkmountainshelter #longcreekfalls #threeforks #chasingwaterfalls💦 #couplegoals❤ #sunshineandwhiskey

children.name: Instagram
caption: This is @deucestarmount (Matt) and Alex about 24-25 years ago. Matt has been contemplating #hiking the #appalachiantrail for longer than Alex has been alive. I’m traveling full-time, so this is a perfect time for him to realize a major bucket list task. I thought I was handling the idea of him being gone quite well. If I was going to get emotional, I thought it would have been when I dropped him off at the #springermountain trailhead or drove from Georgia to Virginia alone. Nope. Nothing until last night, when it finally hit me that he’s likely going to be gone until summer. Welp. Water works. 😭😭😭 It’s fine. It’s going to go by fast. I mean, it feels like we *just* met and that was more than 13 years ago. I would never dream of asking him to come home because I want him to finish possibly almost as much as he does. I’m so happy that he gets to have an adventure. I’m also excited to re-experience some of the things that I enjoyed when I was single. I don’t remember what those things were, but as soon as I do, I’m sure I will be happy to do them again! Matt, if you’re reading this, I miss you so much and I’m so proud of you for making a dream come true! I love you! ❤️❤️❤️ #appalachiantrailclassof2020 #appalachiantrail2020

I was lucky enough to share the start of this monumental moment of one of my dearest and oldest friends!  @cathi.morris made a life changing decision, to take a long walk; 2,200 miles and 14 states, that is, the Appalachian Mountains.  We spent the last few days in a slice of paradise nestled in the North Georgia Mtns.  Our cabin was at the base of Amicalola Falls. This beautiful area is the start of one of the approach trails  to the Appalachian mountains.  She starts her trek from Georgia to Maine!  God Speed, Friend.  So inspired by her, and I always have been!  Cathi and Andrew have been planning her trip and she has been training for well over a year!! She’s amazing, and can always use encouraging thoughts and prayers!  #hikingtheappalachiantrail #appalachiantrail #springermountain #cathimorrisalot #appalachiantrailthruhike2020 #appalachiantrailthruhike

We celebrated 2020 in style, starting the year with our first snowstorm on the trail. For Georgia, it was something else. .
.
Our hike was from Gooch Mountain Shelter to Neel Gap. We had the shuttle driver drop us off at Gooch Gap Friday after work.  We hiked up to Gooch Mountain Shelter and were greeted by none other than Happy Down the Trail!  He started his thru hike on January 1st.  It was great to catch up with him before he continued northbound to Katahdin.  Check him out on his YouTube channel.  Truly an awesome guy!  We spent that evening sleeping inside the shelter.  Of course, Pockets thought she was going to be attacked by mice all night! 🐁 🐭🤣🤣🤣 We woke up to light ran on Saturday morning but started our hike toward Neels Gap.  What amazing views we saw at Woody Gap and Preacher’s Rock!  Absolutely stunning!  Once we hit Lance Creek though, white stuff started falling from the sky.  Pockets, being a true southerner, asked what was falling from the trees.  Shart, having grown up in Northern Idaho, knew exactly what that white stuff was. ❄️ ❄️ By late afternoon, visibility was very low, so we hunkered down at Jarrard Gap. Then commences the snow storm with 25-40 mph winds.  We braved through the night and woke up to a beautiful, winter wonderland. 
Sunday morning was cold to begin with but turned out to be a stunning day as we summited Blood Mountain, the highest point on the AT in Georgia.  Pockets even laid down on a rock on Blood Mountain, almost dozing off because it was so relaxing. .
.
Blood Mountain is a HUGE tourist attraction. And this day was no different than others. We were following a group of day hikers down the mountain and we got off trail. Pockets, in her wisdom, refused to backtrack because she didn’t want to climb over a rock.  BAD idea!  We ended up cutting trail along the side of Blood Mountain for about 1/2 mile.  Next time she’ll climb that rock!🤣🤣🤣 Always an adventure!
.
.
Lessons Learned this Hike:
**Lesson 1–Don’t cut Trail. Rocks won’t hurt you.  The side of Blood Mountain just might!
**Lesson 2–Listen to the Trail.

For the last weekend of 2019, we celebrated by hiking Georgia’s rollercoaster section of the AT between Hawk Mountain Shelter and Gooch Mountain Shelter.  Sassafras Mountain was killer, but we made it. We both drank a liter of water once we came into Horse Gap. Poor Don earned his trail name this weekend after eating a ton of Mexican food Friday night at Hawk Mountain Shelter.  I present to you Shart. 🤣🤣🤣 He wasn’t too thrilled about that. .
.
.
.
Lots of fun times this weekend.  It was our first time to meet Happy Down the Trail—a thruhiker—as he was completing his shakedown hike from Damascus. We would see Happy again!  We had an amazing fire that night. We also met some SOBO thru hikers completing their journey from Maine, a grandfather who has thru hiked twice and his 4 grandsons, and a young guy from the Dominican hiking a longer section.  This is part of what we love about Trail—the community. .
.
.
Saturday was overcast but nice. Sassafras was no joke!  We spent Saturday evening at the shelter with the grandfather and 4 grandsons.  It was raining, so we slept in the shelter...first time ever.  Pockets was freaking out, scared mice would get her all night. The boys played jokes on her all night. 🐁 🐭 Truly fun times! .
.
.
Lessons learned:
1.  Not all rain gear is equal. Our rain gear was like sauna suits. 
2.  Always sleep with your head facing out in a shelter because mice run around the corners.  Thanks, Grandpa!
3.  Don’t eat Mexican 3 straight days unless you want to earn the trail name Shart. 
4.  Ongoing struggle—proper backpacking snacks for maximum energy. 
New Gear Additions We Love:
—Kelty Bestie Blanket—worth every ounce @keltybuilt .
.
.
.

Our very first weekend backpacking in on the Appalachian Trail. It was a short hike from Three Forks to Stover Creek Shelter. . . .
Lessons learned from this hike:
—Lesson 1:  it is possible to overpack a backpack!  As we approached the trail, an elderly guy laughed at us, saying we sure did pack a lot and he could see this being the beginning of a new reality show.  I thought Don was going to lose this crap. I laughed my arse off!
—Lesson 2—Not all camp food is created equal. 😂😂😂Although we are both veterans, the freeze dried meals didn’t do it for us. Thank goodness we met this cute couple who gave us some awesome pointers on tasty backpacking meals. We will be forever grateful to them!😃. ...
—Lesson 3– Car camping gear does not equal backpacking gear!  We took 4.5 lb sleeping bags on this trip!  NOT!  We changed to some awesome Northface Wasatch 45 degree bags for the next weekend. @thenorthface 
Gear that truly worked:
—MSR WhisperLite Camp Stove @msr_gear ...
—Big Agnes Air Core Ultra Sleeping Pad @bigagnes_ —GSI Dualist Cookset— @gsioutdoors —Osprey Kyte 46 backpack— @ospreypacks .

Ready for our next adventure!

Appalachian Trail GA Section Hike 
Day 6 - Dec 16, 2019
Mile 27.7 | Woods Hope Shelter

Overcast skies. Heavy evening storms forecasted so we trekked it to Woods Hole Shelter in case we needed to bunker down. It was a 0.4 mile detour but provided awesome 360 views as we were situated on top of a small summit. 
We took extra precautions setting up our tarps: positioned stakes behind tree roots, added heavy rocks on top of the stakes and lowered the tarp closer to the ground (than what’s shown). Everything held up great and the pups slept with us in our hammocks when the rain and wind picked up. Absolutely loved experiencing the storm that night.

GA has decided to monsoon today, which sucks for me because my campus is huge and i have to walk in it to get to class. we had a tornado warning while i was in PE today (yes, i am required to take one even though i’m a freaking adult 😂) and they made us sit in the locker rooms for a solid 30 minutes but i’m not complaining bc it got me out of class. also I’m amused because for whatever reason, instagram won’t just let me use just the general “Georgia” geotag today and it’s throwing off my organization theme? 😂 not a big deal, it’s whatever, i’m just surprised i wasn’t able to find it. 2nd also: THIS PHOTO WAS SO HARD TO EDIT GAH DANG?? like the lighting was awful oml. glad it’s over with i don’t have a lot of fall photos so i really wanted this one to work with me 😂
